title: 109_s2689
content: In Section 1, there is an increase in tax incentives for alcohol fuels under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments include raising the income tax credit from 60 cents to $1.20 and from 45 cents to 90 cents. Additionally, the timeline for these incentives is extended from 2010 to 2006, with a new item added for the years 2007 through 2010 at $1.02. The excise tax credit for alcohol fuel mixtures is increased from 51 cents to $1.02 and from 60 cents to $1.20. The income tax credit for biodiesel and renewable diesel fuels is raised from $1.00 to $2.00, 50 cents to $1.00, and 10 cents to 20 cents. The excise tax credit for alcohol fuel mixtures and biodiesel is increased. The tax credit for biodiesel mixture is amended to $1.00 and $2.00. Incentives for alternative fuels are also adjusted. The tax credits for alcohol fuel mixtures, biodiesel, and advanced lean burn technology motor vehicles are increased and adjusted. The tax credits for qualified hybrid motor vehicles, qualified alternative fuel motor vehicles, and qualified incremental hybrid cost are increased and adjusted. Tax credits for alternative fuel vehicle refueling property are increased to $60,000 and $2,000. The amendments apply to property placed in service after the enactment of the Act. Elimination of tax incentives for major integrated oil companies. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code eliminates tax incentives for major integrated oil companies related to the amortization of geological and geophysical expenditures. This amendment does not apply to companies with a daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code eliminates tax incentives for major integrated oil companies related to percentage depletion allowance and intangible drilling and development costs. This change applies to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code eliminates tax incentives for major integrated oil companies related to intangible drilling and development costs. This change applies to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. PROHIBITION OF FUNDS FOR OIL AND NATURAL GAS ROYALTY RELIEF. The Secretary of the Interior cannot use funds for royalty relief on oil and natural gas production from Federal land if oil prices exceed $55 a barrel or natural gas prices exceed $10 per 1,000 cubic feet. However, exceptions can be made in cases of natural disasters causing supply disruptions.
